title: Slick Developer's Guide
text: Slick R package designed visualizing exploring results Management Strategy Evaluation (MSE). Slick allows MSE developers analysts prepare MSE results standardized data structure, easily generate publication quality figures tables, present explore MSE results interactive application. document guide analysts wish use Slick summarize present MSE results.

title: Slick Developer's Guide
text: Slick can used rapidly create standardized plots tables MSE results directly R console. See sections examples. plots tables can also viewed Slick App, interactive application developed Shiny. Slick App allows users upload data customize plots filtering management procedures, operating models, performance indicators. App can launched directly R console : App also hosted online. online App publicly accessible can used presenting examining MSE results stakeholders decision-makers. Analysts can either share Slick Object audience directly can upload App, analysts can upload Slick Object Slick Object Library.
code: App()

title: Slick Developer's Guide
text: Slick Object can include following plots: Time Series: Plots time series user-specified variable (e.g., yield, biomass) historical period projection period management procedure. Boxplot: Displays minimum, first quartile, median, third quartile, maximum set results. Includes option display data violin plot. Kobe: Compares performance MPs respect biomass (x-axis) fishing mortality (y-axis). Includes option display data Kobe Time plot, shows percentage runs fall Kobe quadrants projection year. Quilt: table performance indicators management procedure, colored shading indicate better/worse performance. Spider: Shows results three performance indicators, represented axis starting center point. Sometimes also called Radar plot. Tradeoff: Scatter plot comparing two performance indicators. Analysts must include least one plot Slick Object.

title: Slick Developer's Guide
text: use Slick, MSE results must compiled Slick Object. object designed compatible results MSE framework. Slick Object contains information shown plots tables, well metadata information title, introduction, author details. contents Slick Object can grouped following categories: Metadata: information including title, introduction, author details MPs: details Management Procedures OMs: factors, levels, information relating Operating Models Plots: details values Performance Indicators Slick plots

title: Slick Developer's Guide
code: OM_Base <- new('OM', Albacore, Generic_IncE, Generic_Obs, nsim=24)  OM_LowM <- OM_HighM <- OM_Base OM_LowM@M <- OM_Base@M * 0.75 OM_HighM@M <- OM_Base@M * 1.3333  MPs <- c('AvC', 'Itarget1', 'MCD', 'SPmod')  MSE_Base <- runMSE(OM_Base, MPs=MPs, silent = TRUE) MSE_LowM <- runMSE(OM_LowM, MPs=MPs, silent = TRUE) MSE_HighM <- runMSE(OM_HighM, MPs=MPs, silent = TRUE)

title: Slick Developer's Guide

code: Title(slick) <- 'An Example Slick Object' Subtitle(slick) <- "This is the subtitle" Date(slick) <- Sys.Date() Author(slick) <- 'Adrian Hordyk' Email(slick) <-  "[adrian@bluematterscience.com](mailto:adrian@bluematterscience.com)" Institution(slick) <- "[Blue Matter Science](bluematterscience.com)" Title(slick) #> [1] "An Example Slick Object" Subtitle(slick) #> [1] "This is the subtitle" Date(slick) #> [1] "2024-09-18" Author(slick) #> [1] "Adrian Hordyk" Email(slick) #> [1] "[adrian@bluematterscience.com](mailto:adrian@bluematterscience.com)" Institution(slick) #> [1] "[Blue Matter Science](bluematterscience.com)"

title: Slick Developer's Guide
text: exception Date, Markdown can used include links, text styling, etc, text Slick Object. example: Markdown automatically converted HTML App. Use markdown=TRUE argument print HTML code console (document HTML text rendered directly horizontal lines): example Slick object. created purposes demonstrating key features Slick. introduction can include paragraphs well Markdown italics bold text Links.
code: Introduction(slick) <- "  This is an example Slick object. It has been created for the purposes of demonstrating the key features of Slick.  The introduction can include paragraphs as well as Markdown such as *italics* and **bold** text and [Links](https://slick.bluematterscience.com).  " Introduction(slick, markdown = TRUE)

title: Slick Developer's Guide
text: Title, Subtitle, Introduction support multiple languages. Currently three languages supported: en: English es: Spanish fr: French Multiple languages can included providing named list: text throughout Slick Object supports Markdown multiple languages. App dropdown menu allows users select preferred language.
code: Title(slick) <- list(en='This is the English Title',                      es='This is the Spanish Title',                      fr='This is the French Title') Title(slick) #> [1] "This is the English Title" Title(slick, 'es') #> [1] "This is the Spanish Title" Title(slick, 'fr') #> [1] "This is the French Title"

title: Slick Developer's Guide
text: MPs Object contains codes, labels, descriptions management procedures (MPs) included Slick Object, well options colors use plots, preset buttons appear App. Slick Objects must completed MPs Object. easiest way build Slick Object create populate sub-components add Slick Object.

title: Slick Developer's Guide
text: Code, Label required, used plots tables, Description optional. example, 4 MPs: also done : using Metadata function:
code: mps <- MPs() Code(mps) <- c('MP1', 'MP2', 'MP3', 'MP4') Label(mps) <- c('MP 1', 'MP 2', 'MP 3', 'MP 4') Description(mps) <- c('This is an example MP',                       'This MP is a second example',                       'A third example MP',                       'The final example MP') mps <- MPs(Code=c('MP1',                   'MP2',                   'MP3',                   'MP4'),            Label=c('MP 1',                    'MP 2',                    'MP 3',                    'MP 4'),            Description = c('This is an example MP',                            'This MP is a second example',                            'A third example MP',                            'The final example MP')) Metadata(mps) <- data.frame(   Code=c('MP1',          'MP2',          'MP3',          'MP4'),   Label=c('MP 1',           'MP 2',           'MP 3',           'MP 4'),   Description=c('This is an example MP',                 'This MP is a second example',                 'A third example MP',                 'The final example MP') )  Metadata(mps) #>   Code Label                 Description   Color #> 1  MP1  MP 1       This is an example MP #C87A8A #> 2  MP2  MP 2 This MP is a second example #909646 #> 3  MP3  MP 3          A third example MP #00A396 #> 4  MP4  MP 4        The final example MP #9189C7

title: Slick Developer's Guide

code: Color(mps) #> [1] "#C87A8A" "#909646" "#00A396" "#9189C7"  Color(mps) <- colors()[sample(1:100,4)] Color(mps) #> [1] "aquamarine2"   "darkorange4"   "darkgoldenrod" "darkkhaki"  # reset to default colors Color(mps) <- default_mp_colors(4)

title: Slick Developer's Guide
text: Factors data.frame column headings Factor, Level, Description. used describe various factors, levels within factor, operating models included Slick Object. simple example Slick Object includes results 6 OMs, spanning three levels uncertainty natural mortality (M) two levels steepness (h):
code: Factors(oms) <- data.frame(Factor=c(rep('M',3), rep('h',2)),                            Level=c(0.1,0.2,0.3,0.7,0.9),                            Description=c('Natural Mortality = 0.1',                                          'Natural Mortality = 0.2',                                          'Natural Mortality = 0.3',                                          'Steepness = 0.7',                                          'Steepness = 0.9') )  Factors(oms) #>   Factor Level             Description #> 1      M   0.1 Natural Mortality = 0.1 #> 2      M   0.2 Natural Mortality = 0.2 #> 3      M   0.3 Natural Mortality = 0.3 #> 4      h   0.7         Steepness = 0.7 #> 5      h   0.9         Steepness = 0.9

title: Interactive Visualization of MSE Results
text: Slick R package designed visualizing exploring results Management Strategy Evaluation (MSE). MSE involves using closed-loop simulation testing evaluate compare expected performance alternative management methods, often call Management Procedures (MPs), across different hypotheses historical future fishery dynamics, referred Operating Models (OMs). results MSE reported set Performance Indicators (PIs), quantitative measures management objectives fishery stakeholders, managers, decision-makers. Slick allows MSE developers analysts prepare MSE results standardized data structure, easily generate publication quality figures tables, present explore MSE results interactive application.

title: Interactive Visualization of MSE Results
text: Slick released CRAN future. meantime, Slick can installed Github:
code: # install.packages('pak') pak::pkg_install('blue-matter/Slick') library(Slick)

title: Interactive Visualization of MSE Results
text: use Slick, results MSE must available Slick data object. Slick App includes several example data objects. See Developerâ€™s Guide documentation creating Slick Data object MSE results.

title: Interactive Visualization of MSE Results
text: Slick App designed interactively examining MSE results contained within Slick data object. App allows simultaneous presentation various performance metrics can account uncertainty states nature. Slick interactive allows users filter results live order explore robustness performance. Slick can applied decision analysis context specifically designed investigate performance fisheries management procedures tested management strategy evaluation (MSE). Importantly App platform agnostic: results arising MSE framework formatted compatible Slick object can loaded visualized App.

title: Boxplot S4 Object Class â€” Boxplot-class
code: boxplot <- Boxplot(Code=c('PI1', 'PI2', 'PI3'),                    Label=c('Performance Indicator 1',                          'Performance Indicator 2',                          'Performance Indicator 3'),                    Description = c('This is the description for PI 1',                                    'This is the description for PI 2',                                    'This is the description for PI 3'),                    Value=array(runif(3000), dim=c(6, 5, 4, 3)),                    Preset=list('PI and P2'=1:2)  )  boxplot #>  #> â”€â”€ An object of class `Boxplot` â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ #>  #> â”€â”€ `Code` â”€â”€ #>  #> 1 PI1 #> 2 PI2 #> 3 PI3 #>  #> â”€â”€ `Label` â”€â”€ #>  #> 1 Performance Indicator 1 #> 2 Performance Indicator 2 #> 3 Performance Indicator 3 #>  #> â”€â”€ `Description` â”€â”€ #>  #> 1 This is the description for PI 1 #> 2 This is the description for PI 2 #> 3 This is the description for PI 3 #>  #> â”€â”€ `Value` â”€â”€ #>  #>   Dimension Length #> 1      nsim      6 #> 2       nOM      5 #> 3       nMP      4 #> 4       nPI      3 #>  #> â„¹ Mean across MPs and PIs #>       PI1  PI2  PI3 #> MP 1 0.46 0.54 0.52 #> MP 2 0.49 0.57 0.50 #> MP 3 0.45 0.49 0.49 #> MP 4 0.58 0.57 0.52 #>  #> â”€â”€ `Preset` â”€â”€ #>  #> â”€â”€ PI and P2  #> 1 #> 2  Code(boxplot) <- c('LTY', 'STY', 'P50') Metadata(boxplot) #>   Code                   Label                      Description #> 1  LTY Performance Indicator 1 This is the description for PI 1 #> 2  STY Performance Indicator 2 This is the description for PI 2 #> 3  P50 Performance Indicator 3 This is the description for PI 3   # Add to `Slick` object slick <- Slick() Boxplot(slick) <- boxplot  plotBoxplot(slick)   plotBoxplot(slick, type='violin')   plotBoxplot(slick, type='both')

Used label axes charts. Can longer Code recommended keep short possible shows clearly plots tables. character string length nPI named list multi-language support. See Details Time numeric vector values projection time-steps. Must match length nTS Value TimeLab Character string length 1. Name time step (e.g., 'Year'). used label Kobe Time plot. Use named list multiple languages. Value numeric array stochastic performance indicator values simulation (sim), operating model (OM), management procedure (MP), performance indicator (PI), projection time-steps (nTS) Dimensions: c(nsim, nOM, nMP, nPI, nTS) Preset optional named list preset buttons App(). name list element appear button App(). Target Numeric vector length nPI target value PIs. Defines color quadrants Kobe plot. Defaults 1. Limit Numeric vector length nPI limit value two PIs. Shows red line Kobe plot. NULL ignore. Defaults list object default selections Kobe See Kobe-methods()

code: Make_Slick(   name = "Unnamed Slick object",   OM = NULL,   MPs = c("DCAC", "AvC", "Fratio", "FMSYref", "FMSYref50", "matlenlim"),   MP_Desc = NULL,   PMs = c("AAVE", "AAVY", "LTY", "P10", "P50", "P100", "PNOF", "STY", "Yield"),   Design = as.data.frame(cbind(rbind(as.matrix(expand.grid(1:2, 1:3, 1:2)), matrix(1,     nrow = 5, ncol = 3)), c(rep(1, 12), 2:6))),   SN = list(Factor_Labels = c("Natural Mortality", "Resilience", "Stock Depletion",     "Robustness"), Labels = list(c("M=0.2", "M=0.3"), c("h=0.5", "h=0.7", "h=0.9"),     c("Dep=0.1", "Dep=0.3"), c("Ref_Case", "L50=0.5", "Vmaxlen=0.1", "Cobs=0.5",     "Perr=0.5", "AC=0.95")), Codes = list(c("M2", "M3"), c("h5", "h7", "h9"), c("D1",     "D3"), c("Ref_case", "mat_low", "dome", "h_Cerr", "h_Perr", "h_AC")), Description =     list(c("M=0.2", "M=0.3"), c("h=0.5", "h=0.7", "h=0.9"), c("Dep=0.1", "Dep=0.3"),     c("Reference Case",       "L50=0.5", "Vmaxlen=0.1", "Cobs=0.5", "Perr=0.5",     "AC=0.95"))),   mods = list(function(OM, lev) { if (lev == 1) OM@M <- c(0.2, 0.2)      if (lev ==     2) OM@M <- c(0.3, 0.3)      OM  }, function(OM, lev) {      if (lev == 1) OM@h <-     c(0.5, 0.5) if (lev == 2) OM@h = c(0.7, 0.7)      if (lev == 3) OM@h = c(0.9,     0.9)      OM  }, function(OM, lev) { if (lev == 1) OM@D <- c(0.1, 0.1)      if     (lev == 2) OM@D <- c(0.3, 0.3)      OM  }, function(OM, lev) {      if (lev == 2) OM@L50 <- c(0.5, 0.5) if (lev == 3) OM@Vmaxlen = c(0.1, 0.1)      if (lev == 4)     OM@Cobs = c(0.5, 0.5) if (lev == 5) OM@Perr = c(0.5, 0.5)      if (lev == 6)     OM@AC = c(0.9, 0.9)      OM  }),   nsim = 48,   MSElist = NULL,   fstYr = NULL,   returnMSEs = F )

library(Slick) # Assign values to a new `Slick` object slick <- Slick()  Title(slick) <- 'An Example Slick Object' Subtitle(slick) <- "[Created for the Developer's Guide](https://slick.bluematterscience.com/articles/DevelopersGuide.html)" Date(slick) <- Sys.Date() Author(slick) <- 'Adrian Hordyk' Email(slick) <-  "[mailto:adrian@bluematterscience.com](mailto:adrian@bluematterscience.com)" Institution(slick) <- "[Blue Matter Science](bluematterscience.com)"  Introduction(slick) <- " This is an example Slick object. It has been created for the purposes of demonstrating the key features of Slick.  The introduction can include paragraphs as well as Markdown such as *italics* and **bold** text and [Links](https://slick.bluematterscience.com). "  # Access values from `Slick` object Title(slick) #> [1] "An Example Slick Object" Subtitle(slick) #> [1] "[Created for the Developer's Guide](https://slick.bluematterscience.com/articles/DevelopersGuide.html)" Date(slick) #> [1] "2024-09-18" Author(slick) #> [1] "Adrian Hordyk" Email(slick) #> [1] "[mailto:adrian@bluematterscience.com](mailto:adrian@bluematterscience.com)" Institution(slick) #> [1] "[Blue Matter Science](bluematterscience.com)" Introduction(slick) #> [1] "
This is an example Slick object. It has been created for the purposes of demonstrating the key features of Slick.

The introduction can include paragraphs as well as Markdown such as *italics* and **bold** text and [Links](https://slick.bluematterscience.com).
"  # See ?MPs, ?OMs, ?Boxplot, ?Quilt, etc for examples on populating other # objects

title: Plot Boxplot â€” plotBoxplot
code: boxplot <- Boxplot(Code=c('PI1', 'PI2', 'PI3'),                    Label=c('Performance Indicator 1',                          'Performance Indicator 2',                          'Performance Indicator 3'),                    Description = c('This is the description for PI 1',                                    'This is the description for PI 2',                                    'This is the description for PI 3'),                    Value=array(runif(3000), dim=c(6, 5, 4, 3)),                    Preset=list('PI and P2'=1:2)  )  boxplot #>  #> â”€â”€ An object of class `Boxplot` â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ #>  #> â”€â”€ `Code` â”€â”€ #>  #> 1 PI1 #> 2 PI2 #> 3 PI3 #>  #> â”€â”€ `Label` â”€â”€ #>  #> 1 Performance Indicator 1 #> 2 Performance Indicator 2 #> 3 Performance Indicator 3 #>  #> â”€â”€ `Description` â”€â”€ #>  #> 1 This is the description for PI 1 #> 2 This is the description for PI 2 #> 3 This is the description for PI 3 #>  #> â”€â”€ `Value` â”€â”€ #>  #>   Dimension Length #> 1      nsim      6 #> 2       nOM      5 #> 3       nMP      4 #> 4       nPI      3 #>  #> â„¹ Mean across MPs and PIs #>       PI1  PI2  PI3 #> MP 1 0.58 0.45 0.53 #> MP 2 0.55 0.60 0.57 #> MP 3 0.48 0.51 0.50 #> MP 4 0.40 0.55 0.46 #>  #> â”€â”€ `Preset` â”€â”€ #>  #> â”€â”€ PI and P2  #> 1 #> 2  Code(boxplot) <- c('LTY', 'STY', 'P50') Metadata(boxplot) #>   Code                   Label                      Description #> 1  LTY Performance Indicator 1 This is the description for PI 1 #> 2  STY Performance Indicator 2 This is the description for PI 2 #> 3  P50 Performance Indicator 3 This is the description for PI 3   # Add to `Slick` object slick <- Slick() Boxplot(slick) <- boxplot  plotBoxplot(slick)   plotBoxplot(slick, type='violin')   plotBoxplot(slick, type='both')

title: Plot Timeseries â€” plotTimeseries
text: slick Slick-class() object PM_ind numeric value specifying performance indicator plot MP_ind numeric value specifying MP plot. Defaults NULL shows MPs OM_ind numeric value specifying OM plot. Defaults NULL values calculated mean across OMs. OM_label numeric character string providing label OM_ind. Defaults OM_ind missing includeHist Logical. Include historical period projections? col_line Color median line (historical) fill_ribbon1 Fill color inner ribbon col_ribbon1 Color line inner ribbon quants1 Quantiles inner ribbon.
